metadata.case_name: State of Assam vs. Krishna Rao & State of Assam vs. M. D. Bajid

facts.text: Krishna Rao was Garrison Engineer, MES at Jorhat; M. D. Bajid was Assistant Garrison Engineer under him.
Messrs Barakar Engineering and Foundry Works, Calcutta were contractors under MES, Jorhat for supplying fabricated building materials; contract entered by Chief Engineer, Eastern Command.
Contract terms: Contractor entitled to 75% of value of goods supplied through running account bills, vetted first by Bajid.
Two running bills paid up to May 21, 1964.
Krishna Rao allegedly harassed contractor for bribe; expressed desire to agent's expectation of 2% commission.
Third bill delayed on objections to extract bribe.
On August 12, 1964, Krishna Rao demanded bribe from C. L. Noronha (P.W.3, Chief Administrative Officer and attorney of contractor).
On August 13, 1964, Krishna Rao caught accepting Rs.10,000 bribe from Noronha; money smeared with phenolphthalein powder, recovered from his right trouser pocket.
Bajid met Noronha, demanded 3% commission, agreed to Rs.5,000; caught accepting at 4 p.m. on August 13, 1964; money recovered from right trouser pocket.
Trap setup: Peepholes in door between bedroom and office room; independent witnesses Chaliha (P.W.1, Income-tax Officer) and Barua (P.W.2, Sub-Divisional Officer); Kapur (P.W.5, Dy. SP SPE CIA).
Noronha filed written complaint Ex.1 on August 11, 1964 to police.
Krishna Rao's defense: Taken to site by Srivastava and Chatterjee for inspection; Noronha thrust money into pocket; no demand.
Bajid's defense: Called by Chatterjee for site check; Noronha bolted door and thrust money; no demand.
Special Judge, Gauhati convicted both on June 12, 1968: RI 1 year each count u/s 161 IPC and S.5(2) r/w S.5(1)(d) PCA; fines.
High Court (Assam Nagaland at Gauhati) acquitted both on April 30, 1969 in Cr.A. 61/62 of 1968.
Sanction to prosecute: Ex.40 held proper by trial court.
No phenolphthalein test on hands of accused Rao.
Defence witnesses: Shanti Ratna Chakravarty (D.W.1), Avtar Singh (D.W.2), J.A. James (D.W.3) supported accused presence/movement.

legal_issues.text: Whether High Court erred in acquitting accused by doubting peepholes, independent witnesses, and refusing presumption u/s 4 PCA despite recovery of marked currency.
Scope of presumption u/s 4 Prevention of Corruption Act: Arises on proof of acceptance of gratification other than legal remuneration, without needing prior proof of corrupt motive.
Whether trial of Bajid vitiated by non-supply of copies of witness statements from Rao's case.

petitioner_arguments.text: Prosecution evidence on peepholes and eyewitnesses trustworthy; direct evidence of passing money; High Court erred on minor discrepancies and omission of phenolphthalein test.
Recovery of marked currency from pockets raises presumption u/s 4 PCA; defence of thrusting money improbable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.4(1) Prevention of Corruption Act; precedents like State of Madras v. A. Vaidianatha Iyer

petitioner_arguments.text: No prejudice to Bajid from non-supply of copies; separate trials.

respondent_arguments.text: Money thrust into pockets due to grievance; no demand or acceptance with conscious mind.
Doubts on peepholes: No mention in Ex.2, varying sizes, no seizure of tools, material discrepancy.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Brannan v. Peek; Rao S.B. Singh v. State of Vindhya Pradesh

respondent_arguments.text: Independent witnesses not fully reliable; no corroboration of prior demand; presumption requires proof of conscious receipt.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.4 Prevention of Corruption Act (as interpreted by High Court)

court_reasoning.text: Minor discrepancies in peepholes inconsequential; indicate truthfulness; raid party timing shows they witnessed passing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Witnesses reached soon after money passed; front door closed; no other informant.

court_reasoning.text: Presumption u/s 4 PCA arises on proof of receipt of gratification other than legal remuneration; no need for prior proof of corrupt intent; defence version improbable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred in requiring proof of 'conscious mind' before presumption.

court_reasoning.text: No legal entitlement to copies of statements from separate trial; no prejudice to Bajid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Could inspect record or obtain certified copies.

court_reasoning.text: Chaliha and Barua corroborated Noronha; accused behaviour on capture supports prosecution.

holdings.text: Presumption under S.4(1) PCA mandatory on proof of acceptance of money other than legal remuneration; rebuttable by proof, not mere plausible explanation.
High Court judgment set aside; trial court convictions restored.

precedents_cited.relevance: Trap cases to be viewed with circumspection.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rao S. B. Singh & Anr. v. State of Vindhya Pradesh
State of Madras v. A. Vaidianatha Iyer
precedents_cited.relevance: Presumption u/s 4 PCA obligatory on proof of acceptance.

precedents_cited.case_name: C. I. Emden v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Gratification literal meaning; presumption on receipt other than legal remuneration.
Proof of receipt of money raises presumption.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. N. Bose v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Presumption arises on admission/receipt; rebuttal by proof of high probability.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences of public servant taking gratification as motive/reward.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Presumption on acceptance of gratification; punishable offences.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed State's appeals under Art.136 Constitution, set aside High Court acquittal dated April 30, 1969, restored Special Judge's convictions and sentences dated June 12, 1968. Respondents, if on bail, to surrender to serve sentences.
outcome.relief_granted: Convictions under S.161 IPC and S.5(2) r/w S.5(1)(d) PCA restored: RI 1 year each count, fines Rs.1000 (Rao) & Rs.500 (Bajid) with default imprisonment.

key_quotes.text: "Where it is proved that a gratification has been accepted, the presumption under S. 4 of the Prevention of Corruption Act shall at once arise. It is a presumption of law and it is obligatory on the Court to raise it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies mandatory nature of presumption u/s 4 PCA.

key_quotes.text: "The word gratification in s. 4(1) was to be given its literal dictionary meaning of satisfaction of appetite or desire it could not be construed to mean money paid by way of bribe."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope for raising presumption without prior corrupt proof.

key_quotes.text: "The required proof need not be such as is expected for sustaining a criminal conviction it need only establish a high degree of probability."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Onus on accused to rebut presumption.
